section.title: Introduction to the Practice of Statistics

definition.title: statistics
definition.statement: how to collect, organize, summarize and analyze information so that conclusions can be drawn with a measure of confidence.

definition.title: descriptive stats
definition.statement: entails organizing and summarizing collected data.

definition.title: inferential stats
definition.statement: methods for taking sample results and extending it to the population with some measure of reliability.

definition.title: population
definition.statement: entire group of interest in a study

definition.title: individual
definition.statement: a single person or object being studied

definition.title: sample
definition.statement: subset of the population being studied

definition.title: statistic
definition.statement: numerical summary of a sample

definition.title: parameter
definition.statement: numerical summary of a population

definition.title: variables
definition.statement: characteristics of individuals in the population

definition.title: qualitative variable
definition.statement: responses based on attributes or characteristics

definition.title: quantitative variable
definition.statement: responses are numerical measures, with a natural ordering it makes sense to compare via < or >

definition.title: discrete variable
definition.statement: finite or countable number of possible values number of children

definition.title: continuous variable
definition.statement: infinite number of possible values height

reading-questions.title: Statistic or Parameter?
reading-questions.p: For each description which follows, determine whether the numerical quantity is a statistic or parameter.
reading-questions.exercise: In a study of all 2223 passengers aboard the Titanic, it is found that 706 survived when it sank. parameter
A recent survey of a sample of MBAs reported that the average salary for an MBA is more than $82,000. (Source: The Wall Street Journal) statistic
Starting salaries for all of the 667 MBA graduates from the University of Chicago Graduate School of Business increased 8.5% from the previous year. parameter
In a recent poll of Salt Lake Community College students, 83% of students owned a vehicle. statistic
In a recent survey of 457 attendees of Jumanji, 402 would recommend the movie to a friend. parameter, unless you consider the population to be all people who have seen Jumanji

reading-questions.title: Smoker's IQ
reading-questions.p: A study was conducted in which 20,211 18--year old recruits were given an exam to measure IQ. In addition, the recruits were asked to disclose their smoking status. An individual was considered a smoker if he smoked at least 1 cigarette per day. The goal of the study was to determine whether adolescents aged 18 to 21 who smoke have a lower IQ than nonsmokers. It was found that the average IQ of the smokers was 94, while the average IQ of nonsmokers was 101. The researchers concluded that lower IQ individuals are more likely to chose to smoke, not that smoking makes people less intelligent.
reading-questions.exercise: What is the population being studied? adolescents aged 18 to 21
What is the sample? 20,211 18 year old recruits
What are the descriptive statistics? IQ, smoking status

definition.title: response variable
definition.statement: The response variable is the focus of a question in a study or experiment.

definition.title: explanatory variable
definition.statement: An explanatory variable is one that explains changes in the response variable.

definition.title: observational study
definition.statement: measuring response variable without influencing the values of either the response variable or explanatory variable

definition.title: cross-sectional studies
definition.statement: observational studies that collect data at one particular time

definition.title: case-control studies
definition.statement: observational studies that require individuals to look back in time to record measurements (retrospective)

definition.title: cohort studies
definition.statement: observational studies that track individuals repeatedly over time (prospective)

definition.title: designed experiment
definition.statement: measuring response variable after intentionally changing the value of the explanatory variable

definition.title: confounding
definition.statement: in a study occurs when the effects of two or more explanatory variables are not separated. Therefore, any relation that may exist between an explanatory variable and the response variable may be due to some other variable or variables not accounted for in the study

definition.title: lurking variable
definition.statement: a variable that was not considered in the study, but affects the response variable

p.alert: IMPORTANT: Because of the possibility of lurking variables, observational studies DO NOT allow a researcher to claim causation, only association.

definition.title: confounding variable
definition.statement: a variable in the study where you can’t tell the difference between its effect and another explanatory variable’s effect

definition.title: census
definition.statement: list of information from all individuals in a population

reading-questions.title: Observational Study or Designed Experiment?
reading-questions.exercise: Rats with cancer are divided into two groups. One group receives 5 milligrams of a medication that is thought to fight cancer, and the other receives 10 milligrams. After 2 years, the spread of cancer is measured. designed experiment
Conservation agents netted 250 large-mouth bass in a lake and determined how many were carrying parasites. observational study

Seventh grade students are randomly divided into two groups. One group is taught math using traditional techniques; the other is taught math using a reform method. After 1 year, each group is given an achievement test to compare proficiency.
designed experiment
A survey was conducted asking 400 people, "Do you prefer Coke or Pepsi?" observational study

reading-questions.title: Daily Coffee Consumption
reading-questions.p: Is there an association between daily coffee consumption and the occurrence of skin cancer? Reasearchers asked 93,676 women to disclose their coffee drinking habits and also determined which of the women had nonmelanoma skin cancer. The researchers concluded that consumption of 6 or more cups of caffeinated coffee per day was associated with a reduction in nonmelanoma skin cancer.
reading-questions.exercise: Was this an oberservational study or experiment? If observational, what type of observational study was it? observational, cross-section
What is the response variable? What is the explanatory variable? response: skin cancer, explanatory: coffee consumption
Can we conclude drinking six or more cups of coffee reduces the chance of nonmelanoma skin cancer? No, because observational studies never allow us to determine causation, just association.

reading-questions.title: Get Married, Gain Weight
reading-questions.p: Are young couples who marry or cohabitate more likely to gain weight than those who stay single? Researchers followed 8000 men and women for 7 years. At the start of the study, none of the participants were married or living with a romantic partner. The researchers found that women who married or cohabitated during the study period gained 9 pounds more then single women, and married or cohabitating men gained, on average, 6 pounds more than single men.
reading-questions.exercise: Why is this an observational study? What type of observational study is it? No manipulation of explanatory variable; cohort study
What is the response variable in the study? What is the explanatory variable? response: weight, explanatory: marital status
Identify some of the potential lurking variables in the study. diet, exercise, stress, pregnancy
Can we conclude that getting married or cohabitating causes one to gain weight? No, because it is an observational study, not an experiment. We can only conclude that they are associated.

definition.title: random sampling
definition.statement: using chance (an objective device) to select individuals from a population to be included in the sample

definition.title: simple random sample
definition.statement: every sample of a certain size is equally likely (and every subject has an equal chance of being selected)
population size
sample size

definition.title: frame
definition.statement: list of all individuals in a population being studied

definition.title: sampling without replacement
definition.statement: once selected, an individual cannot be chosen again

definition.title: sampling with replacement
definition.statement: once selected, individuals are placed back in the population and can be chosen again

reading-questions.title: Four Tickets for Friends

statement.p: Sophia has 10 friends that she would like to invite to a concert, but only 4 tickets to give away.
Mike, Jamie, Adam, Yvette, Ashley, Monica, Cherie, Julie, Willard, Bruce

reading-questions.exercise:
Which of the following would produce a simple random sample of the 4 friends that she will bring with her:
List each persons name on a piece of paper, place them in a hat and draw 4. yes
List the names in alphabetical order and take the first 4 names. no
Ask one of her friends who she should bring. no
Number the friends from 1 to 10 and use a random number generator to produce 4 numbers between 1 and 10 which correspond to the 10 friends. yes

Use the TI graphing calculator to obtain a random sample of the 4 friends that she will bring with her and give their names.
Thus she would invite Mike, Yvette, Ashley and Julie.
We can also have the calculator sort the list in ascending order:
In this case, she would invite Mike, Jamie, Monica and Willard.

definition.title: stratified sampling
definition.statement: a simple random sample is drawn from each nonoverlapping subgroup (or stratum) into which the population has been separated.
definition.p: Works best when individuals in each stratum are similar in some way and we want to make sure each stratum type is represented. The size of each simple random sample is proportional to the number of individuals in the stratum from which it is selected. ( separating individuals into age groups)

statement.p:
a starting point, p, is randomly selected and then every kth subject is included in the sample, where
k = \lfloor N/n \rfloor.
The brackets, \lfloor x \rfloor, mean round x down to the nearest integer, or take the floor of x.
Subjects in the sample are numbered:
p, p+k, p+2k, p+3k, \ldots, p+(n-1)k

Works best when individuals are arranged sequentially but you’re not sure how many total individuals there are because you don’t have a frame of the population ( files in a drawer, people coming out of a building exit polling, ).
the population is divided into sections or clusters; all individuals from randomly selected clusters are included in the sample.

Works best when individuals are grouped geographically so it makes logistical sense to sample this way, but location does not affect your variable of interest; clusters are heterogeneous like the population.
sampling subjects who are easy to get (bad sampling method).
a convenience sample where individuals are self-selected (another bad sampling method).
Works best when: NEVER!! (not random, favors those with stronger opinions)
a sample that is selected in multiple stages, each of which might use a different method of sampling.
Works best when: The population is organized hierarchically but no list exists.

reading-questions.title: Identify the Sampling Method Part I
reading-questions.exercise: The fifth person exiting the student center and every 12th person afterward is interviewed. systematic sampling
Two out of the six parking lots on campus are randomly selected and every driver in the two lots receives a questionnaire. cluster sampling
Each registered student is assigned a number, 20 numbers are randomly generated and the corresponding students are interviewed. simple random sampling
Six buildings on campus are randomly selected and every 4th person who exits each building is included in the sample. multi-stage sampling; (cluster sampling followed by systematic sampling)
Randomly select 10 males and 10 females in the activity center to be interviewed. stratified sampling
Every person in my class that sits next to me in Math 1040 is interviewed. convenience sampling
A pile of questionnaires is left on a table in the library with a sign that says, “Please complete.” self-selected sampling

reading-questions.title: Identify the Sampling Method Part II
reading-questions.p: For each scenario determine which type of sampling is used.
reading-questions.exercise:
To estimate the percentage of defects in a recent manufacturing batch, a quality control manager selects every 8th chip that comes of the assemply line starting with the 3rd until she obtains 140 chips.
systematic sampling
To determine customer opinion of its boarding policy, Southwest Airlines randomly selects 60 flights during a certain week and surveys all passengers on the flights. cluster sampling

A member of Congress wishes to determine her constituency’s opinions regarding estate taxes. She first divides her constituency into three income classes: low-income households, middle-income households, and upper-income households. She then takes a simple random sample of households from each income class.
stratified sampling

In an effort to identify whether an advertising campaign has been effective, a marketing firm conducts a nation wide poll by randomly selecting individuals from a list of known users of the product.
simple random sampling

A radio station asks its listeners to call in their opinion regarding the use of U.S. forces in peace keeping missions.
self-selected sampling

A college official divides the student population into five classes: freshman, sophomore, junior, senior and graduate student. The official takes a simple random sample from each class and asks the members’ opinions regarding student services.
stratified sampling

section.title: Bias in Sampling

definition.title: bias
definition.statement: when sample results are not representative of the population

definition.title: sample bias
definition.statement: bias because the technique used to select the sample favors some individuals over others (not random)

definition.title: undercoverage
nonresponse bias
definition.statement: bias because individuals in the sample do not respond

definition.title: response bias
definition.statement: bias because responses do not reflect the true feelings or beliefs of the respondent.
definition.p:
Response bias can occur in a number of different ways:
From the interviewerthe nature or wording of the interviewer can affect the truthfulness of responses.
Misrepresented answerswhen the results of a survey misrepresent facts or are flat out lies.
Wording of questionsthe way a question is worded can lead to response bias in a survey.
Ordering of questions or choicesmany surveys will rearrange the order of the questions so that responses are not influenced by prior answers.

definition.title: open question
definition.statement: allows a respondent to choose his or her own response "What is the most important problem facing youth today?"

definition.title: closed question
definition.statement: requires the respondent to choose from a list of predetermined responses.

definition.title: nonsampling errors
definition.statement: errors that result from undercoverage, non-response bias, response bias or data-entry error.

definition.title: sampling errors
definition.statement: errors that result from using a sample to estimate information about a population.
